name: Morpheme
observations: Description: Smallest meaningful unit of language that encodes semantic or grammatical information

name: Lemma
observations: Description: Dictionary form of a word representing its core semantic identity

name: Word
observations: Description: Inflected form of a lemma as it appears in textual context

name: Passage
observations: Description: Coherent unit of text with theological or liturgical significance

name: Trinity
observations: Description: Central Christian doctrine of God as Three Persons in One Divine Essence, encoded in Latin through case relationships and morphological precision

name: Incarnation
observations: Description: Doctrine of God the Son becoming human, expressed through careful tense and aspect choices in Latin theological language

name: Eucharist
observations: Description: Sacrament of Christ's Body and Blood, with theological precision encoded in morphological construction (trans-substantia-tio)

name: FiatLuxToFiatLex
observations: Description: Transformation from divine creative command (fiat lux - let there be light) to systematic legal framework (fiat lex/leges - let there be law/laws), representing the evolution from charismatic divine action to institutional ecclesiastical order

name: PatristicPeriod
observations: Description: Foundational period (100-800 CE) of theological language development, characterized by Jerome's translation choices and patristic theological encoding

name: CarolingianPeriod
observations: Description: Standardization period (800-1000 CE) under Alcuin and Charlemagne, establishing systematic grammatical and liturgical norms

name: ScholasticPeriod
observations: Description: Technical development period (1000-1500 CE) with Aquinas and university theology, creating precise technical theological vocabulary

name: TridendinePeriod
observations: Description: Fixation period (1500-1962 CE) establishing absolute liturgical and theological linguistic standards through Counter-Reformation precision

name: Jerome
observations: Description: Translator of the Vulgate (347-420 CE), whose theological biases and linguistic choices shaped Western Christianity for 1500+ years through systematic translation preferences

name: Augustine
observations: Description: Bishop of Hippo (354-430 CE), major influence on Western theological language through precise doctrinal formulations and anti-heretical precision

name: TheologicalArchaeology
observations: Description: Computational method for detecting theological biases and doctrinal encoding through morphological analysis of translation choices and linguistic patterns

name: JeromeSignatureAnalysis
observations: Description: Specific computational method for identifying Jerome's theological preferences through systematic analysis of his translation choices vs. contemporary alternatives

name: MorphologicalTheology
observations: Description: Method for discovering theological concepts encoded in grammatical structures, revealing doctrine preserved in morphological patterns across centuries

name: FiatTransformationAnalysis
observations: Description: Analysis of the evolution from fiat lux (divine creative command) to fiat lex/leges (systematic legal framework), representing the transformation from charismatic divine action to institutional ecclesiastical order

name: Neo4jGraphDatabase
observations: Description: Graph database storing relational knowledge about ecclesiastical Latin, enabling complex theological and linguistic relationship queries

name: QdrantVectorDatabase
observations: Description: Vector database enabling semantic similarity search across theological concepts and linguistic patterns through embedding-based retrieval

name: PostgreSQLAuditSystem
observations: Description: Relational database maintaining chronological audit logs and metadata for all analytical operations and discoveries

name: SQLiteInterface
observations: Description: Portable relational database providing practical access interface for pastoral and educational applications

name: HybridKnowledgeGraph
observations: Description: Integrated knowledge management system combining graph, vector, and relational databases with UUID-linked entities for comprehensive theological and linguistic analysis
